question: Summarize the following evidence in 2-3 sentences.

content.source_1: I’ve been hunting for the original Starbucks mocha blend for ages because the stores near me don’t carry it. I ordered the Costco two-pack—two 2.5 lb tins—and started making café-style mochas at home with a single shot of espresso and about two tablespoons of the mix in steamed milk. The flavor comes together the way I remember from the café, with that rounded cocoa note that doesn’t taste chalky or thin. It dissolves cleanly if I add it before the milk, and the tin’s wide mouth makes scooping easy even half-asleep in the morning. Between my partner’s nighttime cocoa and my afternoon mochas, one tin lasts us a few weeks without the taste getting stale. Shipping took a bit because it’s heavy, but everything arrived sealed and fresh.
content.source_2: I’m weighing this strictly on price. The Costco bundle is 80 ounces total, which sounds great until you look at the per‑ounce math from my zip: by the time shipping is added, it’s noticeably more than the 16‑ounce grocery canister I can occasionally snag on sale, and definitely above the store brand cocoa. The weight pushes the delivery fee up, and there’s no option to buy a single tin to test the waters. If you make cocoa a couple of times a month, the upfront cost sits on your shelf for a long time. I wish there were smaller sizes or regional availability so I didn’t have to commit to two big tins just to try it.
content.source_3: I care most about how it performs in the cup. Using two tablespoons in 8 ounces of steamed milk, it blooms quickly and doesn’t leave gritty residue at the bottom—even without a whisk. In a mocha, I pull a double espresso into the mug first, then stir in the powder before adding milk, and it gives a deep cocoa backbone that doesn’t get drowned by the coffee. My kids make straight cocoa with hot water and a splash of cream, and it keeps a silky texture instead of going sludgy. The aroma is classic Starbucks—cocoa-forward with a hint of roast—and the sweetness lands in a comfortable spot without masking the chocolate.
content.source_4: I bought this expecting café‑style mochas, but the mix leans heavily on sweetness for my palate and the cocoa depth feels thin. Even with careful stirring, I’ve had clumps that only break up with a whisk, and there’s a syrupy film on the mug afterward. Side‑by‑side with the mocha from my local Starbucks, this comes off more like dessert than a coffeehouse drink, and the balance gets lost once you add espresso. My family tried it for a week and most of us ended up going back to our usual unsweetened cocoa plus simple syrup, which gives more control over the sweetness and texture.
content.source_5: I’m in a town where neither the grocery stores nor the local Starbucks carry the original blend, so ordering the Costco pack was the only way to get it. The two 2.5 lb tins are giant; they arrived in a single box with air pillows, and one lid had a small dent but the inner seal was intact. I split the powder into smaller mason jars for the pantry and kept one tin sealed for later—there’s a “best by” date that gives plenty of time. The size is handy for hosting; we did a hot cocoa bar for a birthday, and having a big tin meant no mid‑party run. I wish single tins were available so storage wouldn’t be a puzzle in a small kitchen.
content.source_6: Looking at both taste and value, I use one to two tablespoons per cup, and a single 2.5 lb tin gives me roughly 60–70 mugs depending on how generous I scoop. Per cup, it comes out far below what I’d pay at the café for a mocha, but higher than plain bulk cocoa powder from the warehouse aisle. That said, the blend is more rounded than basic cocoa plus sugar and saves me steps in the morning. The tins are sturdy and reseal well, so the powder stays fresh even after a month on the counter. If you drink mochas regularly, the two‑tin Costco pack keeps you stocked, and it’s easy to make consistent drinks without fussing with separate ingredients.
